title: Lesson 11: The Cell Cycle and Interphase
moduleTitle: Cells as the Basis of Life
description: Understanding the cell cycle phases with focus on interphase (G1, S, G2). Students learn about cell growth, DNA replication, and checkpoint control.
learningIntentions: Students can describe the three phases of interphase (G1, S, G2) and the activities occurring in each.
Students can explain why interphase occupies the majority of the cell cycle time.
Students can interpret data showing the relative duration of cell cycle phases.

syllabusLinks.inquiryQuestion: IQ1: What distinguishes one cell from another?

successCriteria: I can list the events of G1, S, and G2 in correct order.
I can explain why the S phase is critical for accurate cell division.

engagementHook.title: The Waiting Game
engagementHook.content: 'Your skin replaces itself every 2–4 weeks. If you look at skin cells under a microscope, 90% of them look 'boring'—no chromosomes moving, no cells pinching in half. Are they sleeping? No. They're preparing for the most complex operation a cell performs: creating an exact copy of itself. Today we explore the preparation phase that takes up 90% of a cell's life.'

keyConcepts.definition: Interphase (G1, S, G2) + Mitotic phase (M phase: mitosis + cytokinesis). Interphase = ~90% of cycle.
Cell growth, synthesis of organelles and proteins, normal metabolic activities. 'Decision point' here determines if cell will divide.
DNA replication (chromosomes duplicated to form sister chromatids), synthesis of histones, centrosome duplication begins.
Continued growth, synthesis of proteins needed for mitosis (tubulin for spindle), checks DNA for errors before M phase begins.
Surveillance mechanisms ensuring previous phase completed correctly before proceeding (simplified as 'quality control').

misconceptions.correction: Interphase is highly active—cell is growing and replicating DNA. 'Gap' refers to gap between divisions, not inactivity.
DNA replication is in S phase (interphase), not during M phase. Mitosis is separation of already-replicated DNA.

misconceptions.misconception: All cells divide at the same rate
misconceptions.correction: Different cell types have different cycle lengths (skin cells fast, nerve cells slow/non-dividing).

contentSections.title: The Cell Cycle Clock
contentSections.content: Circular diagram showing Interphase (G1 → S → G2) taking up 90% of circle, M phase (mitosis) small segment. Pie chart style or linear timeline.
contentSections.example: Cancer cells often have shortened G1 or lost checkpoints (connect to uncontrolled division).
contentSections.checkForUnderstanding: If a total cell cycle is 20 hours, approximately how many hours are spent in interphase? (Answer: ~18 hours).

contentSections.title: When Checkpoints Fail
contentSections.content: Brief introduction to p53 as 'guardian of the genome' (simplified). If DNA damage detected in G1 or G2, cell cycle pauses for repair. If damage too severe, cell undergoes apoptosis (programmed death—link to Lesson 6 lysosomes/apoptosis).
contentSections.example: Skin cancer (melanoma) from UV damage—cells with damaged DNA divide uncontrollably because checkpoints failed.

multipleChoice.question: During which phase of the cell cycle does DNA replication occur?
multipleChoice.rationale: Core S phase definition. DNA synthesis/replication occurs during S phase of interphase.

multipleChoice.question: A cell spends approximately 90% of its time in:
multipleChoice.rationale: Interphase proportion. G1 + S + G2 = ~90% of cell cycle.

options: Ensure the cell is ready for division and check for DNA errors
multipleChoice.correctAnswer: Ensure the cell is ready for division and check for DNA errors

shortAnswer.question: Describe the events occurring during the S phase of the cell cycle. (2 marks)
markingCriteria: 1 mark: DNA replication occurs / chromosomes are duplicated (forming sister chromatids)
1 mark: Synthesis of histone proteins / duplication of centrosomes (or cell prepares for division)

shortAnswer.question: Explain why interphase occupies the majority of the cell cycle time. (2 marks)
markingCriteria: 1 mark: Cell must grow (increase mass, duplicate organelles) and replicate DNA accurately (S phase takes time)
1 mark: Preparation and checking mechanisms (G2) ensure accurate division/prevent errors (or mention synthesis of proteins needed for division)
shortAnswer.commonError: Saying 'the cell is resting' rather than preparing.

definitions: The cell cycle consists of Interphase (G1, S, G2) and the M phase (mitosis and cytokinesis).
G1: Cell growth and organelle duplication.
G2: Preparation for mitosis and final growth/checks.

shortAnswer: During the S phase of the cell cycle, DNA replication occurs. Each chromosome is duplicated to form two identical sister chromatids joined at the centromere. Additionally, histone proteins are synthesised to package the new DNA, and centrosome duplication begins in preparation for cell division.

Interphase occupies the majority of the cell cycle because the cell must complete several critical processes before division. During G1, the cell grows and duplicates organelles. During S phase, DNA replication must occur accurately, which requires significant time to ensure faithful copying of the entire genome. During G2, the cell synthesises proteins needed for mitosis (such as tubulin for spindle fibres) and performs quality control checks to verify DNA integrity. These preparation steps are essential for producing healthy daughter cells.
